div.l: And herd one crye watir as he were wood .
And thouȝt alas now cometh noes flood
And sette him up withouten wurdis mo
And there with an ax he smote þe cordis in two
And doun goth alle he found neithir to selle
Breed ne ale . but shortly doun he felle
Vpon the flour and ther in swoun he lay
Vp stert Alisoūn and hend Nicholay
And cried out and harou in the strete
The neiȝbours both smale and grete
Be comen forto gaure on this man
That in swoun lay white palissh ⁊ wan
For with that falle borsten had he his arme
But stond he must vnto his ovne harme
For whan he spak he was born a doun
With hend Nicholas and Alisou
They told euery man that he was wode
He was agast so of Noes flood
Thurgh fantasy that of his vanite
He had goten him Tubbis thre
And had hem hangid in the roof aboue
And that he preid hem for goddis loue
To in the roof ꝑper cumpany
The gan laugh at his fantasy
And to e roof they kiken and they gape
And turnid alle his harme vnto a iape
For what so this carpinter ansuerd
It was for nought no man his resou herd
With othis gret he was y born a doun
That he was holden wood in alle þe toun
For euery clerk anone held with othir
They seid the man was wood my lef broþꝰer
And euery wight gan laugh at þis strife
Thus swyued was the carpinters wife
For alle his keping and his ielousy
And Absolon hath kist hir nethir eye
And Nicholas is scallid in his toute
This tale is done and god saue al þe rout
The Prolog of the Reve
Whan folk han laught at this nyce caas
Of Absolon and of hend Nicholas
Diuerse folk diuersly they seid
But for the more part they laughid and pleyde
